key_insight: Neural stochastic differential equations that learn state-dependent drift and diffusion can accurately model continuous-time, noisy cell dynamics and generate realistic trajectories, enabling simulation of developmental and disease perturbations. This generative approach outperforms prior methods on single-cell temporal modeling.
problem_solved: Existing models struggle to represent continuous, stochastic cell-state trajectories and to simulate realistic responses to perturbations; this paper provides a flexible, interpretable generative model that captures state-dependent noise and drift.
method: Parametrize cell dynamics as neural stochastic differential equations (neural SDEs) that learn state-dependent drift (deterministic flow) and diffusion (noise magnitude) functions.
Train the model end-to-end on single-cell time-series or snapshot datasets to match observed trajectory distributions and latent dynamics.
Use the learned generative SDE to sample realistic trajectories and perform counterfactual/perturbation simulations (e.g., gene knockouts or treatment effects).
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners with a principled continuous-time generative framework for noisy, heterogeneous biological dynamicsâ€”useful for improved simulation, hypothesis testing, and synthetic data generation in computational biology and beyond.
visual_elements: Schematic of a neural SDE: vector field (drift) arrows + shaded noise cone (diffusion) learned by neural nets
Trajectory plots: overlay of observed single-cell states and generated continuous-time stochastic trajectories
Perturbation panel: before/after simulation showing predicted effect of a genetic or drug perturbation
Bar/line chart comparing predictive/generative performance against baseline methods
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
